profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 00:03

did.abstract: The collection consists of both private and institutional bookplates from Denmark, bookplates by Danish artists, and ephemeral materials related to the collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Yale Bookplate Collection was formerly housed in Sterling Memorial Library. The collection was incorporated into the Arts of the Book Collection in 1984 and then moved to the Seeley G. Mudd Library in 1990. In 2011 it was transferred to the Robert B. Haas Family Arts Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to Yale University.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Collection of Danish Bookplates, Robert B. Haas Family Arts Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Some materials included in this collection indicate the provenance of the following collectors: Baron Gunnar Trönnberg of Sweden, Arvid Berghman, Erik N. Ellert, and A. Bernard C. K. Keeves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of both private and institutional bookplates from Denmark as well as ephemeral materials related to the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series and one addition: I. Bookplates - Individuals. II. Bookplates - Organizations, Institutions, and Businesses. III. Bookplates - Artists; 2015 Addition.

The arrangement preserves the original alphabetical ordering by which special letters and those with diacritical marks were sorted at the end of the alphabet. Any correspondence or ephemeral materials relating to a specific bookplate are filed together with the bookplate.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by the patron's surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from Køhler with enclosed bookplate.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: A collection of various library, university, social organization, and business bookplates arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Bispebjaerg Hospital – Instituttet For Salg Og Reklame

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes bookplates organized by artist. See also Folder 101, which includes two lists of artists.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by the artist's surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a portfolio of 15 bookplates published in 1952 by the Danish Ex-libris Society.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The typed list has the heading "Helmer Fogedgaard - Box 9 - Rudköbing - Danmark" and includes abbreviations for the techniques in creating and printing bookplates, as devised by the International Federation of Ex-libris Societies (FISAE).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Friedrich (Frederik) Britze, Johannes Britze, and Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes ex-libris designed by Friedrich (Frederik) Britze (1870-1956), a German-Danish engraver and printmaker. He was the father of Johannes Britze (1895-1960), who was also a bookplate artist, engraver, and painter.
The series also includes historical examples of Danish bookplates, bookplates of Danish royalty, and other ephemera.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by the patron's surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 116 contains a copy of Heraldikeren Frederik Britze; En dansk Exlibriskunstner by Poul Reitzel, published in 1945.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by the patron's surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a bookplate exchange form belonging to Haagen Bartram-Jensen, dated October 21, 1959, and a list of ex-libris by Johnny Køhler.
